page.title: 11CHESTERFIELD CANAL
page.content: THE MAIN CARGOES CARRIED WERE COAL, CORN,LEAD,BRICKS AND GENERAL GOODS.THE VOLUME OF TRAFFIC WAS GOOD BUT AS WITH OTHER CANALS THE COMING OF THE RAILWAYS MEANT A DECLINE IN THE TRADE CARRIED.THE CANAL RAN AT A LOSS AFTER 1888 AND THE CLOSURE OF THE NORWOOD TUNNEL(MENTIONED PREVIOUSLY) MEANT THAT THE TRENT WAS CUT OFF FROM THE MAIN SOURCE OF CARGOES.THE LAST COMMERCIAL TRAFFIC TO USE THE CANAL WAS IN 1955.EVEN AT THAT TIME THE COMMERCIAL TRAFFIC WAS HORSE DRAWN WHICH ENABLED THE BANKS OF THE CANAL TO BE MAINTAINED IN GOOD CONDITION. IN THE EARLY PART OF THE 1960'S THE CANAL WHICH HAD TENDED TO BE BLOCKED BY PLANT LIFE WAS CLEARED FOR USE AS A WATERWAY BY MEMBERS OF THE RETFORD AND WORKSOP BOAT CLUB. SINCE THAT TIME THROUGH THE WORK OF THAT GROUP MORE OF THE CANAL HAS BEEN OPENED.
